title: How We As A Generation Have Mastered The Art Of 'Disappearing'

How We As A Generation Have Mastered The Art Of 'Disappearing'

How We As A Generation Have Mastered The Art Of 'Disappearing'

We don't say goodbye anymore.

We don't officially end our relationship with them. However insignificant or major it was it in our lives, we don't give them closure. Instead, we stop responding to their calls, let their unread text messages pile up on our phone.

If we ever see them, we pretend like we don't know them. We act as if we never woke up to them every single day and spoke to them. We so effortlessly let it slide from our mind that they were our favourite 'hello' and our most precious 'goodnight'. We treat each other like strangers.

And that's because it's easier to disappear. An art that our generation would probably be known by, for years to come.

Pexels

So why don't we say goodbye?

Why can't we leave with dignity by respecting the other person who really doesn't deserve this cold, dead lifetime of silence.

We as a generation lack this sensitivity. We don't explain. We couldn't care enough to see if the other person is okay. How they are coping without us. We just take off. We start speaking to another person to fill incomplete voids. We associate happiness with a destination and end up booking tickets to run away.

Because disappearing is believed to be cooler than staying.

Pexels

So we disappear. Because obviously we'll do what's cool, right?

We disappear because disappearing is stronger, disappearing makes you the one in control, so we keep disappearing instead of staying and wonder why we end up alone or in unfulfilling relationships.

Oh and the biggest irony of all, we disappear and stay up all night waiting to be found.

Pexels

Instead, say goodbye. Let them know they mattered. Let them know what went wrong.

Choose to be the 'good' in the 'goodbye'.
